Author: fauigerzigerk
Content: Forget it! No one over the age of 15 will ever make it big ;-) Seriously, you have all the time in the world. Study the hard core stuff (algorithms, data structures and maths). Experiment with the web. Seek out people who really take interest in whatever they do. Don't burden yourself with debt, expensive lifestyle or kids, so you have the freedom to jump onto opportunities whenever they present themselves.

Author: iamelgringo
Content:
It depends if you have private loans or federal.

You can typically ask for 3x 6 month "hardship" deferments on Federal Stafford loans on top of your 6 month grace period after you graduate. And, those deferments are re-set if you go back to school for a semester. So, theoretically, you could take 18 months worth of deferment and then go back to school for a semester, drop out, and take another 18 months of hardship deferment.

There are also repayment programs available to you if you have limited income. At lest a few years ago, there was a type of repayment program where you could pay a fixed percentage of your income for 30 years, and then your loans were considered paid in full. I remember reading about a Rhode Island School of Design film student who got a $150,000 film degree. That's the repayment program that she was in, so she could make ends meet and still pursue her art.

Now, if your student loans are to private lenders, that's a whole different ball of wax. They usually aren't as understanding. \n

Author: davidw
Content:
Which of course have nothing at all to do with north eastern Italy:-) Your average Sicilian or Neapolitan wouldn't have a clue what a 'spritz' was in the sense of the drink.

Actually, the original term came from when the Austrians occupied the area, and imported what is still called a "spritzer" here in Austria, which is just wine and fizzy water. In the Veneto they took it and improved it by adding the bitter.

Ok, wildly off topic, but it's kind of interesting, and if you're ever in Padova or Venice, I highly recommend having a spritz in the piazza.

Author: almost
Title: Ask news.yc: Taking payments for third parties?
Content:
Hi all!

I'm considering an idea that involves taking credit card payments from consumers on behalf of my customers.

I'd need to collect the payments then, after the service had been supplied, send it on to the seller (by cheque or bank transfer probably). I'd be basically acting as an online storefront.

Does anyone have an experience of the problems I'm going to encounter here? I imagine there could be problems with liability when holding other peoples money or issues when refunds need to be made.

I'm based in the UK so I'm mainly interested in how it works with the laws here but I'd presumably want to expand out at some point so any advice about elsewhere would be useful too.

All advice will be much appreciated, thanks!

Author: Tichy
Content: At a recent barcamp some bloggers mentioned something interesting: they treat their visitors differently with regard to ads: the feed subscribers only see ads on an article after a few weeks, whereas people hitting the blog through search engines see ads from the start. Not sure what the right mixture would be, but it's something worth to think about, I guess.

Author: mqt
Content:
You could use vilisp.vim[1], which will basically copy-and-paste Lisp forms into your REPL for you. If you use OSX, you can try pg's method[2] of dragging text between terminals.

Better yet, you could resurrect Slim-Vim[3] if you really want SLIME-like features.

[1]: http://www.vim.org/scripts/script.php?script_id=221

[2]: http://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=72863

[3]: http://wiki.alu.org/Slim-Vim

Author: DarrenStuart
Content: If they are not going to pay you how are you being employed would be my first question. I would walk away unless they offer at least 30%. I'll be honest I wouldn't touch it with a bargepole. Lets face it they might have an idea but you will not get any credit for building it and whats stopping them from replacing you at anytime. 2% of nothing is worth less than nothing.
